content.webTitle: Steve McClaren: Newcastle’s new signings can help seal survival

fields.headline: Steve McClaren: Newcastle’s new signings can help seal survival
fields.bodyText: Steve McClaren has said he is confident Newcastle United will escape relegation and claimed he does not fear for his job. Failure to beat West Bromwich Albion at St James’ Park on Saturday would dent such optimism considerably, though, leaving McClaren’s team stuck in the bottom three with his position under intense scrutiny. “It’s a big game,” acknowledged a manager who, despite Newcastle’s £80m investment in new players this season, has only three fit senior defenders and no specialist left-back available to face Tony Pulis’s side. “But we’ve been in this position all season, so it’s nothing new for us. “On Wednesday night [when Newcastle lost 3-0 at Everton] Roberto Martínez said we reminded him of his old Wigan team during those years when they were in the Premier League’s bottom three for most of the season. He said that in the last 10 games they used to pull some results together and get out of it. They had the talent and, in the last 10 games of the season, they decided to come together as a team.” For a club with a pre-season aim of finishing in the top eight and possibly winning a cup, aiming to emulate a Wigan team who eventually got relegated and is now in League One represents quite a come down. Right now though, staying up is Newcastle’s sole ambition. “I honestly think we can survive,” said McClaren. “Especially with the players we’ve signed in January [Jonjo Shelvey, Andros Townsend, Henri Saivet and Seydou Doumbia]. We have 12 senior players injured at the moment though, which no one really takes into account. “Whoever I play at left-back against West Brom won’t be happy because it won’t be their natural position – and Steven Taylor [who has been sidelined by a hamstring injury for five months] will come back at centre-half earlier than we expected.” This lack of defensive options raises the question as to why Newcastle failed to invest in a new left back and centre half during January. “It certainly wasn’t through a lack of effort but we couldn’t foresee losing three players at Everton,” said McClaren who saw Paul Dummett and Chancel Mbemba sustain hamstring and ankle injuries respectively at Goodison Park where Jamaal Lascelles was also sent off. While Dummett, a left-back or centre-half, could be out for around a month, the principal concern is Mbemba, who has impressed in central defence this season. Initial scans of his ankle have suggested he could be set for a lengthy absence and he has appointments to see two specialists early next week. Taylor’s only game since tearing a hamstring in August has been a behind closed doors practice match at Sunderland which Newcastle lost 6-0 but McClaren hopes he can reprise his once impressive partnership with Fabricio Coloccini. “It’s great for Steven Taylor,” he said. “He’s been working hard and it’s been a long very, very frustrating time for him. He’s a true Geordie, he’s a Newcastle boy and he wears his heart on his sleeve. We will need his kind of character and commitment tomorrow.”
